narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was given incredible insight into the screenwriting process and industry from this class.

In this class I learned the foundations of what it takes to become a screenwriter. I was exposed to a high volume of professional screenplays, and was asked to perform writing activities associated with many of the scripts I wrote which helped me develop a more critical and keener eye in terms of what makes good screenwriting. Similarly, we were constantly workshopping our scripts both in and out of class, and at the end of the class we were expected to have written a complete 8-12 page screenplay. This helped me understand how to flush a complete story with a concrete beginning, climax, and ending. Overall, I have learned so much from this class and I am so excited to take Intermediate Screenwriting to build on the knowledge I gained this semester.
I learned: screenwriting format, how to build character, how to evaluate other screenplays and what makes a good one.

I learned how to write a short screenplay. I learned a lot about how to format a screenplay, how to properly evaluate what makes a good screenplay and express it in words, and how to make a screenplay exciting.
I learned a lot about the basics of screenwriting and tools famous screenwriters and directors have utilized to make their films great.
Foundations to screenwriting, script analysis, types of generic tropes/

A deep understanding of screenplay strategy, preparation, and execution. I learned how multiple genres function and the nuances required to create a screenplay that gives leeway to actors and directors, but engages the reader.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The content of this class was incredibly strong, and I felt that I really learned a lot about screenwriting. The in-class workshops were also extremely helpful; this aspect of creative writing classes has always been enjoyable and valuable.

There were no weaknesses in this class, I loved absolutely every moment of it. Obviously, I wish it could've been in person, but that is the only thing that didn't make this class completely perfect. Our 2 hour virtual seminar meetings allowed me to develop great and close bonds with both my professor and all the other students in the class. The strength of the class is based mainly in how both personable and knowledgeable Professor Lapadula is. He makes learning about screenwriting seriously engaging because he looks directly at your work, and you get to workshop both your own work and the work of your classmates, this highly hands-on experience allows you to make changes and understand what about your own writing works and what doesn't. I truly don't think this class can be improved upon, it is amazing.

The class is well organized, with a good balance between lecture, discussion, and meeting in small groups outside of class. There were effectively two homework assignments, a midterm and a final, both of which took a fairly long time to complete. It might be more kind to split up when certain components of each folder are due.

Strengths: It's fun! Brainstorming ideas for a short film, writing the screenplay, and workshopping it--as well as workshopping my classmates' screenplays--was a lot of fun. It's a really cool thing to be able to do in an academic environment.

Weaknesses: It's hard. You have to figure out quite a lot on your own with regards to actually making a short screenplay. You are given examples of previous students' work, and you are given feedback on your script in the workshop, as well as in your discussions with your small group, but you need to figure out many things on your own. I think having a text of some form to read with the class about the basics of story structure could be very helpful. Much of the class consisted of watching clips from films and the professor explaining why the clips are exciting/a good scene. I think that reading a professional short script and breaking down the story structure in the first couple weeks could be extremely helpful, as well as potentially reading some short essays about typical story structure. For students that have never written fiction before, it can be very difficult to try and write a good, successful story without a sense of what makes a story work.
Seminars are very interactive. Professor Lapadula can go on a few rants here and there, but understandable, given the scope of what we're covering.

This course has been my favorite taught at Yale so far. There is a level of engagement and dedication to its students through personal meetings and discussion of movies as they relate to the writing that I havent found in any other media course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class didn't seem much different than it would have been in person.

The virtual engagement for this class ended up being beneficial in some ways, because when we had to read each others scripts, the screen sharing of zoom made that a lot easier, similarly it was also really easy to watch clips of films that helped aid with class. I can't think of anything that really needed to be improved upon.
The discussion groups outside of class worked well, and the class was still very engaging. I was grateful that Marc usually gave us a 5 minute break.
Given COVID, nothing could be done better. Does feel like it is missing out because of the lack of human presence.
The class was small enough to be engaging over zoom. It worked very well. In order to keep this, I WOULD NOT increase the class size. It made it doable over zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No. Assignments aren't helpful, and lectures can be unrelated to screenwriting sometimes.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in becoming a screenwriter.

I would absolutely recommend this course, because a combination of both Professor Lapadula's fun and enthusiasm as well as the hands on learning we do through workshopping, this class really does have everything, and it made me fall in love with screenwriting.
As a course it might not be the most useful for non-majors, but take it if Marc Lapadula is teaching.

Only if they hope to take intermediate and advanced screenwriting afterwards. The majority of this course involves you teaching yourself how to write a script, and it is fun to do so and have yourself evaluated by your peers; however, you can do this on your own if you want by reading Save the Cat (or some other book on screenwriting) and then having a group of friends read/workshop your writing. Much of what this class teaches can be learned in other ways, and so I would only recommend it if you are dying to write longer screenplays later on and hope to do so in an academic setting.

Yes. You learn some good, verified tips from someone who's still active in the screenwriting business. You also get to hang out with a small group of classmates from the class every week and read some really cool work.
Yes. I had a lot of fun in the class and enjoyed the work we did.
Take it! Lapadula is a great teacher of how to write a basic screenplay. He really gets you into the whole process and you leave wanting to go to Hollywood.
Without question. A professor who is willing to call you on the phone to discuss a midterm portfolio is one you need to learn from.
